These expressions both refer to two major weather conditions in the year. Translators may use local expressions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: cold and heat, summer and winter

contextId.occurrenceNote: "men of all ages." This merism emphasizes that the visitors blinded all the men. This could indicate social standing rather than age. Alternate translation: "both small and great" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

"the God of heaven and earth." The words "heaven" and "earth" are used together to mean every thing that God created. Alternate translation: "the God of everything in heaven and earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: the God of heaven and the God of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "good nor bad" are used together to mean "anything." Alternate translation: "Do not say anything to try and stop Jacob from leaving" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: Be careful that you speak to Jacob neither good nor bad

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "good nor bad" are used together to mean "anything." See how you translated this in [Genesis 31:24](../31/24.md). Alternate translation: "Do not say anything to try and stop Jacob from leaving" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: Be careful that you speak to Jacob neither good nor bad

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "firstborn" and the "youngest" are used together to mean all the brothers were sitting in order according to their age. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: the firstborn according to his birthright, and the youngest according to his youth
